elements.content: A family of two-dimensional (2D) Zn-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with exitonic emission have been successfully synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. When isophthalic acid ligands with different substitutions are introduced, the crystal structures and fluorescence properties are significantly changed. Hirshfeld surface calculation is used to study the nuances of diverse substitutions during the construction of all of the crystals. The solid fluorescence results indicate that there are obvious two-channel emissions, including intralayer excimers and interlayer trapped excitons, both in 1 and 2 with a double-layer structure and in 3 with a single-layer structure, mainly exhibiting intralayer emission. Furthermore, the fluorescence changes on morphology transformations are explored after mechanical exfoliation consisting of grinding and ultrasonicaation of MOFs 1–3. The regulation and control of crystal structure and morphology can suppress emission based on interlayer excitons, achieving adjustment of the overall emitting color. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of 2D bilayer MOFs with dual-channel emissions, which provides a new structural model for synthesizing new exciton materials.

elements.content: Three new 2D Zn-based MOFs have been successfully synthesized through introducing isophthalic acid ligands with different substituents. There are obvious two-channel emissions in 1 and 2 with double-layer structure. The fluorescence changes of MOFs 1−3 with morphology transformations have been explored after mechanical exfoliation.

elements.content: Two-dimensional (2D) metal–organic framework (MOF) materials, which are newly emerging inorganic–organic hybrid 2D materials, have attracted wide attention since the report of single-layer graphene in 2004. Owing to their large surface area and more reachable active sites, 2D MOF materials have shown great potential application in gas adsorption and separation, nanoporous membranes, catalysis, chemical sensing, electronics, and energy storage.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Two-dimensional (2D) metal-organic framework (MOF) materials, which are newly emerging inorganic-organic hybrid 2D materials, have attracted wide attention since the report of single-layer graphene in 2004. Owing to their large surface area and more reachable active sites, 2D MOF materials have shown great potential application in gas adsorption and separation, nanoporous membranes, catalysis, chemical sensing, electronics, and energy storage.

elements.content: However, research on 2D inorganic–organic hybrid exciton materials, one kind of semiconductor material that has potential application value in advanced photonic fields, has been relatively sparse, although there have been many reports on 2D MOF materials. Belov and co-workers reported a 2D material and used it for synchronous optical information processing and recording. Pan’s group designed a novel two-dimensional layer Ca-MOF with dual-channel emissions, including intralayer excimers and interlayer trapped excitons, in which the overall illuminating color and states of optical register in different Ca-MOF samples can be manipulated through morphological transformations. The research of Lin’s group has shown that excitons are more easily obtained on a 2D material because energy transfer of 2D metal–organic layers (MOLs) is more efficient than that of 3D materials.

elements.content: How to effectively manipulate the synthesis of a specific structure to get target MOFs with specific properties is an enormous challenge, although their structures are diversified owing to the diversity of organic ligands. At present, numerous researchers are focused on the directional design and preparation of complexes with certain properties. The direct synthesis of complexes with different structures by using the substituent effect is an effective method widely used for the regulation of the structures of complexes. More importantly, the properties of the substance change as the structure changes; thus, it is easy to achieve regulation of complex properties at the molecular level by transformation of the substituents.
elements.clean_text: How to effectively manipulate the synthesis of a specific structure to get target MOFs with specific properties is an enormous challenge, although their structures are diversified owing to the diversity of organic ligands. At present, numerous researchers are focused on the directional design and preparation of complexes with certain properties. The direct synthesis of complexes with different structures by using the substituent effect is an effective method widely used for the regulation of the structures of complexes. More importantly, the properties of the substance change as the structure changes; thus, it is easy to achieve regulation of complex properties at the molecular level by transformation of the substituents.

elements.content: To achieve 2D layered structures in MOFs, the rational selection of organic ligands is extremely essential. Of the common ligands, the flexible pyridine ligand with S atoms and the common bridge ligand 5-substituted isophthalic acids were selected. Owing to the larger atomic radius of S atoms, the flexible ligand has many configurations that result in realizing several incredible structures through self-assembly with metal nodes. In addition, isophthalic acids have many derivatives with different substituents that are helpful in comparing structures with different substituents. In this paper, the V-shaped flexible ligand 1,2-bis­[(pyridin-4-ylthio)­methyl]­benzene (bpb) and three isophthalic acids, i.e., 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,3-H2bdc), 5-methylisophthalic acid (H2mip), and 5-tert-butylisophthalic acid (H2tbip), were used to build a new series of 2D Zn-MOFs. Hirshfeld surface analysis, an effective tool, was used to study not only the intermolecular interactions but also the effect of substituents in the process of the construction of MOFs 1–3. The substituent effect is used to regulate the 2D layered structure and layer spacing so that the fluorescence properties of block crystals MOFs 1–3 are different. MOFs 1 and 2 with a double-layer structure and the single-layer MOF 3 exhibit dual-channel fluorescence emissions, but the interlayer trapped excitons play a major role in 1 as well as 2; the spectrum associated with the intralayer excimers is the main body in compound 3. Moreover, by mechanical grinding and ultrasonic peeling, the interlayer emission of complexes is weakened and the fluorescence regulated. In addition, compounds 1–3 have been characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography, infrared (IR) spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), ultraviolet–visible-light (UV–vis) absorption, spectrum scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), among other methods.

elements.content: 1,2-Bis­[(pyridin-4-ylthio)­methyl]­benzene (bpb) was synthesized according to literature reports. All of the other reagents and solvents used in the experiment were commercially available and were used without further purification. The IR absorption spectra of all of the ligands and 1–3 were collected using KBr pellets on a Thermo Scientific FTIR-Nicolet iS10 spectrometer in the range 4000–400 cm–1. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out with an Elementar Vario ELIII analyzer. PXRD patterns of these compounds were recorded on a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Ultraviolet diffuse reflection spectra were measured on a Hitachi U-4100 spectrometer, in which there is an integrating sphere and a BaSO4 plate used as a standard (100% reflectance). Luminescence spectroscopy of all of the compounds was performed on a Lengguang (Shanghai, China) F98 fluorescence spectrophotometer, and polarization-dependent photoluminescence studies were performed on a Hitachi F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The time-resolved emission measurements were measured on a Quantaurus-Tau Fluorescence lifetime spectrometer (Hamamatsu). TGA data were acquired using a Mettler-Toledo simultaneous thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C under an N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Molecular Hirshfeld surface calculations were performed using the CrystalExplorer 3.1 program, and all of the images were generated at the highest resolution. The morphology of several sprayed gold samples was observed using a field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM; Nova NanoSEM 450, 10 kV), a transmission electron microscope (TEM; JEM-2100, 200 kV), and an atomic force microscope (AFM; SPA-400SPM).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

1,2-Bis[(pyridin-4-ylthio)methyl]benzene (bpb) was synthesized according to literature reports. All of the other reagents and solvents used in the experiment were commercially available and were used without further purification. The IR absorption spectra of all of the ligands and 1-3 were collected using KBr pellets on a Thermo Scientific FTIR-Nicolet iS10 spectrometer in the range 4000-400 cm-1. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out with an Elementar Vario ELIII analyzer. PXRD patterns of these compounds were recorded on a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Ultraviolet diffuse reflection spectra were measured on a Hitachi U-4100 spectrometer, in which there is an integrating sphere and a BaSO4 plate used as a standard (100% reflectance). Luminescence spectroscopy of all of the compounds was performed on a Lengguang (Shanghai, China) F98 fluorescence spectrophotometer, and polarization-dependent photoluminescence studies were performed on a Hitachi F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The time-resolved emission measurements were measured on a Quantaurus-Tau Fluorescence lifetime spectrometer (Hamamatsu). TGA data were acquired using a Mettler-Toledo simultaneous thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C under an N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Molecular Hirshfeld surface calculations were performed using the CrystalExplorer 3.1 program, and all of the images were generated at the highest resolution. The morphology of several sprayed gold samples was observed using a field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM; Nova NanoSEM 450, 10 kV), a transmission electron microscope (TEM; JEM-2100, 200 kV), and an atomic force microscope (AFM; SPA-400SPM).

elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (29.7 mg, 0.1 mmol), bpb (6.4 mg, 0.02 mmol), 1,3-H2bdc (3.3 mg, 0.02 mmol), DMF (0.6 mL), and H2O (0.9 mL) was sealed in a 5 mL Teflon-lined reactor and heated at 110 °C for 24 h. When the mixture was cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals of 1 were obtained in 70% yield based on bpb. Anal. Calcd for C29H31N3O7S2Zn: C, 52.53; H, 4.71; N, 6.34. Found: C: 52.81; H: 4.52; N, 6.44.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of the bpb ligand and 1–3 were selected and mounted on glass fibers for XRD analysis. Crystal data were collected on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K with the ω-scan technique. Empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. All of the structures were determined by direct methods using SHELXS-2014/7 and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least squares with the SHELXL-2014/7 package. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were located in different Fourier syntheses and finally refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined using the riding model. For complex 3, the contribution of one free water molecule was treated as diffuse using the squeeze procedure implemented in the PLATON program. Details of the crystal data as well as details of data collection are summarized in . Selected bond lengths, angles, and hydrogen bonds are given in Tables S1–S4 (see the Supporting Information). CCDC 1871593–1871596 (bpb ligand and 1–3) contain supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystals of the bpb ligand and 1-3 were selected and mounted on glass fibers for XRD analysis. Crystal data were collected on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K with the ω-scan technique. Empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. All of the structures were determined by direct methods using SHELXS-2014/7 and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least squares with the SHELXL-2014/7 package. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were located in different Fourier syntheses and finally refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined using the riding model. For complex 3, the contribution of one free water molecule was treated as diffuse using the squeeze procedure implemented in the PLATON program. Details of the crystal data as well as details of data collection are summarized in . Selected bond lengths, angles, and hydrogen bonds are given in Tables S1-S4 (see the Supporting Information). CCDC 1871593-1871596 (bpb ligand and 1-3) contain supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.

In a typical abrasive stripping experiment, 100 mg of the crystal sample was placed in an agate mortar, manually ground, and recorded for time. Then, samples collected at different times were used for fluorescence, morphology observations, and powder diffraction measurements. In a ultrasonic peeling experiment, 5 mg of the ground sample was dispersed in 5 mL of DMF and sonicated for 30 min in an ultrasound bath (Kedao, SK8200B, 500 W, 35 kHz).
elements.clean_text:
Exfoliation and Morphology Transformation by Mechanical Exfoliation

In a typical abrasive stripping experiment, 100 mg of the crystal sample was placed in an agate mortar, manually ground, and recorded for time. Then, samples collected at different times were used for fluorescence, morphology observations, and powder diffraction measurements. In a ultrasonic peeling experiment, 5 mg of the ground sample was dispersed in 5 mL of DMF and sonicated for 30 min in an ultrasound bath (Kedao, SK8200B, 500 W, 35 kHz).

elements.content: MOFs 1–3 were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. For the three complexes, although their synthesis conditions are similar, the substituent effects of the acids and the versatile conformation of the bpb ligand exert an important influence on the resulting architectures ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

MOFs 1-3 were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. For the three complexes, although their synthesis conditions are similar, the substituent effects of the acids and the versatile conformation of the bpb ligand exert an important influence on the resulting architectures ().

elements.content: Single-crystal XRD analysis reveals that the bpb ligand crystallizes in the triclinic system with the space group P1̅. As displayed in a, the asymmetric unit is composed of a bpb molecule with anti-V shape. An organic supramolecular structure is formed through the hydrogen-bond interactions between bpb ligands, as shown in b, in which there is π–π accumulation between adjacent pyridine rings from different bpb ligands (c) with a distance of 3.629 Å to generate a one-dimensional (1D) chain.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure

Single-crystal XRD analysis reveals that the bpb ligand crystallizes in the triclinic system with the space group P1̅. As displayed in a, the asymmetric unit is composed of a bpb molecule with anti-V shape. An organic supramolecular structure is formed through the hydrogen-bond interactions between bpb ligands, as shown in b, in which there is π-π accumulation between adjacent pyridine rings from different bpb ligands (c) with a distance of 3.629 Å to generate a one-dimensional (1D) chain.

elements.content: The single-crystal XRD studies performed on 1 and 2 reveal that they are 2D isoreticular frameworks. Compound 1 was used as the sample with which to study their crystal structures, which crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P1̅ and exhibits a (2,4)-connected corrugated 2D structure. The asymmetrical unit of 1 consists of one ZnII, one coordinated water, one 1,3-bdc2–, one bpb ligand, one lattice water, and one DMF molecule. As shown in a, ZnII is five-coordinated with a ZnO3N2 coordination environment and displays a distorted-trigonal-bipyramidal geometry: one O atom from the coordinated water molecule, two carboxylate O atoms from different 1,3-bdc2– ligands (bond lengths of Zn–O ranging from 1.959(3) to 2.158(3) Å), and two N atoms from two bpb ligands (Zn–N bond lengths of 2.049(4) and 2.258(4) Å). Along the c axis, bpb acts as a bridging coordination ligand with mode I () to connect Zn­(II) into a 1D [Zn­(bpb)] n chain (b), while, from the a axis, Zn­(II) is linked by 1,3-bdc2– in bis-monodentate mode to form a 1D [Zn­(1,3-bdc)] n chain, and the benzene rings from adjacent acid ligands are almost on the same plane (c). Then, such two different chains are assembled into a 2D layer structure along the ac plane (d). The adjacent layers are further connected to obtain a bilayer structure via O5–H5B···O2 H bonds between carboxylate O atoms of 1,3-bdc2– and H atoms from coordinated water molecules and C12–H12A···O4 between O atoms of 1,3-bdc2– and H of the bpb ligand (e,f). The 3D supramolecular structure is generated by stacking of bilayers with van der Waals interactions (Figure S1). In addition, the X-ray structure of compound 2 is shown in Figure S2.

Compound 1 was used as the sample with which to study their crystal structures, which crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P1̅ and exhibits a (2,4)-connected corrugated 2D structure. The asymmetrical unit of 1 consists of one ZnII, one coordinated water, one 1,3-bdc2-, one bpb ligand, one lattice water, and one DMF molecule. As shown in a, ZnII is five-coordinated with a ZnO3N2 coordination environment and displays a distorted-trigonal-bipyramidal geometry: one O atom from the coordinated water molecule, two carboxylate O atoms from different 1,3-bdc2- ligands (bond lengths of Zn-O ranging from 1.959(3) to 2.158(3) Å), and two N atoms from two bpb ligands (Zn-N bond lengths of 2.049(4) and 2.258(4) Å). Along the c axis, bpb acts as a bridging coordination ligand with mode I () to connect Zn(II) into a 1D [Zn(bpb)] n  chain (b), while, from the a axis, Zn(II) is linked by 1,3-bdc2- in bis-monodentate mode to form a 1D [Zn(1,3-bdc)] n  chain, and the benzene rings from adjacent acid ligands are almost on the same plane (c). Then, such two different chains are assembled into a 2D layer structure along the ac plane (d). The adjacent layers are further connected to obtain a bilayer structure via O5-H5B⋅⋅⋅O2 H bonds between carboxylate O atoms of 1,3-bdc2- and H atoms from coordinated water molecules and C12-H12A⋅⋅⋅O4 between O atoms of 1,3-bdc2- and H of the bpb ligand (e,f). The 3D supramolecular structure is generated by stacking of bilayers with van der Waals interactions (Figure S1). In addition, the X-ray structure of compound 2 is shown in Figure S2.

elements.content: Compound 3 is also a 2D structure, which crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit contains one ZnII, one bpb ligand, one tbip2– ligand, and one free water molecule. Different from 1 and 2, ZnII in 3 exhibits a 4-coordinated tetrahedral geometry with a ZnO2N2 coordination environment as shown in a, and it is surrounded by two N atoms (Zn–N bond lengths of 2.043(16) and 2.066(17) Å) and two carboxylic O atoms (Zn–O bond lengths of 1.945(14) and 2.005(18) Å) from two bpb ligands and two tbip2– ligands, respectively. In the direction of the b axis, it is noted that bpb ligands link ZnII ions to yield two kinds of 1D screw chains with long pitches of 22.51 Å (b), in which the bpb ligand is in mode II (). However, in the bc plane, carboxyl ligands bridge the adjacent 1D chains of [Zn­(bpb)] n (c) to become a 2D layer network (Figure S3). The adjacent layers are future-stacked with each other through H bond interactions (d,e). In addition to the H bond interaction, significant π–π accumulations between pyridine and benzene rings from adjacent layers are observed, as illustrated in Figure S4.

elements.content: Hirshfeld surface analysis is a useful tool with which to study the intermolecular interactions of two different crystal structures and can give a detailed explanation of the immediate environment of a molecule in a crystal. The 3D Hirshfeld surface mapped with d norm and 2D fingerprint plots of the bpb ligand and MOFs 1–3 are shown in and and Figures S5–S8, and the surfaces are shown as transparent to allow visualization of the molecular moiety around which they were calculated.
elements.clean_text:
Hirshfeld Surface Analysis

Hirshfeld surface analysis is a useful tool with which to study the intermolecular interactions of two different crystal structures and can give a detailed explanation of the immediate environment of a molecule in a crystal. The 3D Hirshfeld surface mapped with d norm and 2D fingerprint plots of the bpb ligand and MOFs 1-3 are shown in  and  and Figures S5-S8, and the surfaces are shown as transparent to allow visualization of the molecular moiety around which they were calculated.

elements.content: As shown in , the red area denotes strong interactions, which is mostly hydrogen bonding including N···H and S···H. This can be seen clearly from 2D fingerprint plots (Figure S5): apart from H···H interactions (44.0%), hydrogen bond interactions account for nearly half (48.2%; C···H/H···C, 25.3%; N···H/H···N, 12.3%; S···H/S···H, 10.6%). In a, the regions in bright red of 1A are the interactions between hydroxyl oxygen O–H and O, including Ocoordinated water–H···ODMF, Ocoordinated water–H···Ocarboxyl, and Ofree water–H···Ocarboxyl, and the remaining red is the coordination bond effect. The significant intermolecular interactions mapped on the molecular surface can be clearly presented through 2D fingerprint plots (Figure S6). Upon comparison to 1, the Hirshfeld surface analysis and fingerprint plots (Figure S7) of 2 are similar, as shown in b, and the regions in bright red of 2A are assigned to the interaction between hydroxyl and O, including Ocoordinated water–H···ODMF, Ocoordinated water–H···Ocarboxyl, and Ofree water–H···Ocarboxyl, which is consistent with the structural analysis. For 3, the region of 3A in c is a strong H bonding interaction between H from the free water molecule and O of carboxyl.

elements.content: To better understand the different interactions in complexes 1–3, the statistical results of relative contributions in fingerprint plots are shown in . The strong H···H interactions with one distinct spike in the 2D fingerprint plots (Figures S6 and S7) contact dominantly with their contribution varying from 37.6% to 39.1% for 1 and 2, respectively, while the 41.9% of 3 (Figure S8) is significantly higher than that. The fingerprint plots of proportions of O···H/H···O interactions are not highly coincident, although the proportions (19.0%, 18.1%, and 19.0%) in all of the complexes are much the same. The distinct spikes of O···H/H···O reciprocities in 1–3 indicate that they play an important role in intermolecular interactions. In addition, the percentages of S···H/H···S interactions are not much different among the three compounds. The total contribution of O···H/H···O and S···H/H···S interactions in 1–3 is about one-fourth (25.8, 25.1, and 25.8%, respectively). The C···H/H···C interaction on behalf of the C–H···π interlayer interactions of 1 and 2 cover 24.2% and 22.8%, respectively, but in 3 (18.1%) it is clearly narrower. In addition, the weak C····C interaction, which refers to π–π stacking, occupies 2.5%, 3.0%, and 5.9% in 1–3, respectively. It is worth noting that the contribution of the π–π interaction in 3 is obviously higher than that in 1 and 2.

elements.content: As noted above, we find that the bpb ligands are able to bend and rotate freely, showing two kinds of modes that are different from the configuration of the free ligand (). It is evident that the flexibility of the bpb ligand exerts a significant effect on the architecture of the coordination polymers. MOFs 1–3, each having the same bpb ligand, metal ions, and different 5-substituted isophthalic acids with similar coordination models (), have been synthesized under similar conditions, but their structures are not identical. Although all of the structures of MOFs 1–3 display 2D lamellar structures, compounds 1 and 2 possess novel double-layer structures and 3 exists in the usual single-layer structure. This is because mode I of the bpb ligand with syn-V shape was employed for 1 and 2, and mode II of bpb with an outline of “Z” was adopted for 3.
elements.clean_text:
Effects of Ligands on Structure of Compounds

As noted above, we find that the bpb ligands are able to bend and rotate freely, showing two kinds of modes that are different from the configuration of the free ligand (). It is evident that the flexibility of the bpb ligand exerts a significant effect on the architecture of the coordination polymers. MOFs 1-3, each having the same bpb ligand, metal ions, and different 5-substituted isophthalic acids with similar coordination models (), have been synthesized under similar conditions, but their structures are not identical. Although all of the structures of MOFs 1-3 display 2D lamellar structures, compounds 1 and 2 possess novel double-layer structures and 3 exists in the usual single-layer structure. This is because mode I of the bpb ligand with syn-V shape was employed for 1 and 2, and mode II of bpb with an outline of "Z" was adopted for 3.

elements.content: In addition to the effect of bpb ligands, substituents of isophthalic acids also have some minor effects during the assembly of complexes. When the H atom of the 5-position of isophthalic acid is replaced by a methyl group, the structure of 2 is similar to that of compound 1, attributed to a smaller steric hindrance of the methyl group.

elements.content: The structures of 1 and 2 are similar, indicating that the structures are not affected much, attributed to the steric hindrance effect of the methyl group being relatively small. An interesting result obtained through Hirshfeld surface analysis is that the H bond interaction marked as i (a) disappears when the H atom of the 5-position is replaced by a methyl group (b). Owing to this minor change, the interlamellar spacing of 2 is smaller than that of compound 1, but the single-layer thickness of 2 becomes larger than that of 1 owing to the steric effect of methyl.

elements.content: The solid fluorescence of MOFs 1–3 bulk crystals was measured at room temperature (a), showing emission peaks at 536 and 545 nm for 1 and 2 (λex 384 nm) and at 469 nm for 3 (λex 420 nm). Under UV light, the bulk crystal samples of MOFs 1–3 showed different colors of fluorescence: light green for 1, yellow for 2, and light blue for 3 (b). To better study the fluorescence properties of the complexes, the fluorescent emission of all of free ligands was tested at room temperature, as shown in Figure S9. For the bpb ligand, there exist two peaks, at 447 and 535 nm, and for 1,3-H2bdc, H2mip, and H2tbip, the strongest emission peak is at 387, 495, and 320 nm, respectively. Interestingly, the emission peak of the bpb ligand at 535 nm vanished in DMF solution (Figure S9a), which may be due to the loss of ordered intermolecular accumulation.
elements.clean_text:
Photophysical Properties of Bulk Crystals 1-3 

The solid fluorescence of MOFs 1-3 bulk crystals was measured at room temperature (a), showing emission peaks at 536 and 545 nm for 1 and 2 (λex 384 nm) and at 469 nm for 3 (λex 420 nm). Under UV light, the bulk crystal samples of MOFs 1-3 showed different colors of fluorescence: light green for 1, yellow for 2, and light blue for 3 (b). To better study the fluorescence properties of the complexes, the fluorescent emission of all of free ligands was tested at room temperature, as shown in Figure S9. For the bpb ligand, there exist two peaks, at 447 and 535 nm, and for 1,3-H2bdc, H2mip, and H2tbip, the strongest emission peak is at 387, 495, and 320 nm, respectively. Interestingly, the emission peak of the bpb ligand at 535 nm vanished in DMF solution (Figure S9a), which may be due to the loss of ordered intermolecular accumulation.

elements.content: Further studies of excitation spectra monitored for MOFs 1–3 at various emission wavelengths have found that block crystals of 1 and 2 visibly exhibit two main peaks at 384 and 410 nm for 1 (a) and at 384 and 407 nm for 2 (d) with varied intensities at different monitoring wavelengths, and 3 has one main peak at 417 nm and one unnoticeable shoulder peak at 345 nm (Figures S10a and S11a). Then the bpb ligand was studied by a similar experimental method, and two main peaks at 371 and 390 nm were easily observed, but the other peak of 410 nm was not obvious (Figure S12a). The intensity of the emission peak increases with the change of excitation wavelength in Figure S12b, which is different from the fluorescence emissions of MOFs 1 and 2 discussed in detail later.

elements.content: The emission spectra of 1 and 2 bulk crystals displayed an uncommon excitation-dependent change tendency (b,e). For high-energy excitations (λex 320–384 nm), a strong emission peak can be monitored at 536 nm for 1 and at 545 nm for 2. Furthermore, lowering the excitation energies (λex 390–425 nm) will result in settlement of this emission, and a shoulder emission peak of short wavelength above 480 nm becomes evident, while the emission peak of 536 nm gradually diminishes. However, this phenomenon of wavelength change was not observed in 3, and the intensity of the peaks at 469 and 488 nm increased gradually with the change of wavelength excitation from 350 to 420 nm (Figures S10b and S11b). To further verify the two fluorescence emissions of compounds 1 and 2, the time-resolved emissions of all complexes and the bpb ligand were measured at room temperature, as shown in Figures S13–S15. All emission lifetimes, including those of the complexes and bpb, exhibited the characteristics of a typical single-exponential curve at room temperature, and they were 3.89 ns for 456 nm and 3.22 ns for 536 nm in MOF 1, 4.04 ns for 474 nm and 5.83 ns for 545 nm in MOF 2, 4.23 ns for 469 nm in MOF 3, and 3.15 ns for 447 nm and 3.27 ns for 535 nm in bpb, respectively. In addition, polarization-dependent photoluminescence of MOFs 1–3 and the bpb ligand were measured, as shown in Figures S16 and S17. The results showed that fluorescence at 536 nm for 1, 545 nm for 2, and 447 and 535 nm for the bpb ligand were related to the orientation, but peaks at 456 nm of 1 and 474 nm of 2 and the fluorescence emission of MOF 3 had little correlation with the direction.

elements.content: According to the two excitation spectra, double emission peaks, and the results of time decay, as well as the 2D double- or single-sheet structures of MOFs 1–3, we consider that the phenomenon can be attributed to double-channel emission pathways as reported in the literature, which has rarely been reported in MOFs and MOF materials. The strong emission above 500 nm can be related to interlayer exciton capture by the 2D layers after interligand charge transfer, and the emission below 500 nm can be attributed to the excimer intralayer. In compounds 1 and 2, the dual-emission peaks are at 456 and 536 nm for 1 and at 474 and 545 nm for 2, respectively. However, in 3 the intralayer excimer at 460 nm is the main peak, and the interlayer trapped exciton at 531 nm is weaker.

elements.content: In both 1 and 2, the emission of bulk crystals has a distinct excitation-dependent transfer tendency, which can be considered attributable to the emission-characteristic-related semiconductor materials. Then, the measurements of the UV–vis absorption spectrum for MOFs 1–3 were carried out at room temperature (Figure S18), translated from the solid UV diffuse reflectance spectra by the Kubelka–Munk equation. The peak below 400 nm should be ascribed to π–π* and n−π* transitions of ligands. As shown in , the corresponding well-defined optical absorption associated with E g can be assessed at 3.20 eV for 1, 3.17 eV for 2, and 3.04 eV for 3, which indicates that MOFs 1–3 really are potential semiconductor materials.

elements.content: To summarize the above findings, the crystalline materials of 1 and 2 can be considered excitonic materials with interlaminar emission. To test our hypothesis, the fluorescence changes of MOFs 1–3 were tested after grinding for different times. As expected, the peak intensities at 536 nm for 1 and at 545 nm for 2 become weaker with increasing grinding time, as well as the luminescent colors being divided from green (1) or yellow (2) to blue, respectively (a,b), owing to which should occur the destruction of the long-range orderly 3D stacking structure. The interlayer emission channel gradually disappears with the destruction of the 3D stacked structure, leading to the gradual weakening of the peak at 536 nm for 1 and 545 nm for 2. As the milling time is increased, the samples would be ground more uniformly, causing more crystal structure to be destroyed. As shown in c,d, SEM images of 1 and 2 display apparent lamellar morphology after grinding for 30 min, and no crystal samples are present, which means interlayer emission channels largely disappeared. One noteworthy point is that the fluorescence degree of the powder sample is apparently higher than that of the crystal of 3 after grinding for 1 min, with the possible reason being that the sample becomes more uniform after mechanical lapping (Figure S19). The fluorescence change after 2 min may be due to the transformation of sample morphology, but it is not similar to that of 1 and 2. To further verify the mechanism, we also tried to grind the bpb ligand to study the fluorescence change. As shown in Figure S20, the peak intensity at 535 nm became weaker with increasing grinding time, and the peak at 445 nm increased gradually. After grinding for 5 min, there was no significant change in fluorescence, which may be ascribed to the abundant weak interactions between bpb molecules acting as buffers to make stacked structures less vulnerable to damage. Although the bpb ligand also showed the phenomenon of fluorescence weakening due to mechanical dissection, this should be attributed to its special stacking structure. That in MOFs 2 and 3 should be attributed to their special stacking structure based on double layers.

As expected, the peak intensities at 536 nm for 1 and at 545 nm for 2 become weaker with increasing grinding time, as well as the luminescent colors being divided from green (1) or yellow (2) to blue, respectively (a,b), owing to which should occur the destruction of the long-range orderly 3D stacking structure. The interlayer emission channel gradually disappears with the destruction of the 3D stacked structure, leading to the gradual weakening of the peak at 536 nm for 1 and 545 nm for 2. As the milling time is increased, the samples would be ground more uniformly, causing more crystal structure to be destroyed. As shown in c,d, SEM images of 1 and 2 display apparent lamellar morphology after grinding for 30 min, and no crystal samples are present, which means interlayer emission channels largely disappeared. One noteworthy point is that the fluorescence degree of the powder sample is apparently higher than that of the crystal of 3 after grinding for 1 min, with the possible reason being that the sample becomes more uniform after mechanical lapping (Figure S19). The fluorescence change after 2 min may be due to the transformation of sample morphology, but it is not similar to that of 1 and 2. To further verify the mechanism, we also tried to grind the bpb ligand to study the fluorescence change. elements.content: We also studied the liquid sonication of MOF 1–3 powder samples in DMF. After ultrasonication for 30 min, we observed the Tyndall effect through the supernatant fluid in all samples (Figure S21), indicating that the powder samples were scattered to nanoscale particles. Furthermore, the Tyndall effect was not observed in series settled solutions of bpb ligand sonicated for 30 min, which indirectly negated the breakdown of skeleton structures of MOFs 1–3 into metallic salts and organic ligands.
elements.clean_text: We also studied the liquid sonication of MOF 1-3 powder samples in DMF. After ultrasonication for 30 min, we observed the Tyndall effect through the supernatant fluid in all samples (Figure S21), indicating that the powder samples were scattered to nanoscale particles. Furthermore, the Tyndall effect was not observed in series settled solutions of bpb ligand sonicated for 30 min, which indirectly negated the breakdown of skeleton structures of MOFs 1-3 into metallic salts and organic ligands.

elements.content: The nano- and microstructures of nanoscale particles obtained by ultrasonication were characterized in detail by SEM, TEM, and AFM, evidencing the formation of structures with nanometer size ( and Figures S22 and S23). As shown in , obvious nanoparticles with dimensions of hundreds of nanometers were observed by SEM and TEM, and AFM images of the nanoballs deposited onto quartz showed sizes ranging from 5 to 60 nm, indicating microspheres of 1 fabricated by ultrasonication were not evenly distributed. In the case of 2, although some of the clumps were not stripped, visible nanosheets were visible (Figure S22a), which was also confirmed by TEM (Figure S22b), and AFM images of nanosheets showed thicknesses of 18.2 and 28.7 nm (Figure S22c). In the case of 3, new rodlike crystals with uniform size were observed in SEM and TEM images as shown, in Figure S23a,b, and we concluded that the powder of MOF 3 underwent dissolution and recrystallization in DMF to give crystals of micrometer size. AFM images of selected rodlike crystals showed a height of 66 nm (Figure S23c). The phenomenon of dissolution and recrystallization was found in 3 but not in 1 and 2, indicating that the systems in which powder samples of 1 and 2 are dispersed in DMF are relatively stable.

elements.content: The fluorescence spectra of MOFs 1–3 were then measured, as shown in , demonstrating that the intramolecular fluorescence emissions of MOFs 1–3 may mainly come from the bpb ligands and that the exciton interlayer emissions vanish. Then the time-resolved emissions of MOFs 1–3 and bpb in DMF, which were essentially the same, were tested and fitted, as shown in Figure S24. The fluorescence lifetimes were 1.60 ns for 1, 1.58 ns for 2, 1.60 ns for 3, and 1.61 ns for the bpb ligand, respectively, and the values of R 2 are greater than 0.99.

elements.content: To evaluate the phase purity, PXRD patterns of MOFs 1–3 were recorded. As shown in Figures S25 and S26, the experimental PXRD patterns of polymers 1–3 demonstrate good agreement with the simulated patterns. In addition, the trend of intensity change in the PXRD patterns for 1 and 2 ground for different times indicates that the long-range ordered 3D accumulation structures were gradually destroyed, and peaks marked with asterisks gradually disappear with time (Figure S27). The PRXD of recrystallized sample 3 deposited on a piece of glass verified the process of dissolution and recrystallization in DMF (Figure S26). To examine the thermal stabilities of MOFs 1–3, TGA studies were carried out (Figure S28). The TGA curves of 1 and 2, which resemble each other, show an initial weight loss of 15% (calcd 13.7% for 1; calcd 13.4% for 2) before 165 °C for 1 and 170 °C for 2, corresponding to the weight loss of one free water and one DMF molecule. The rapid weight loss is attributed to decomposition after 300 and 290 °C for 1 and 2, respectively. For 3, there is no obvious weight loss before 250 °C, which suggests that the skeleton is thermally stable, and the weight loss above 270 °C should lead to the collapse of the structure. The IR spectra of all of the organic ligands and the complexes were recorded at indoor temperature (Figure S29). In comparison to carboxylic acid ligands, characteristic peaks of carboxyl groups at 950, 1275, 1690 and 2500–3300 cm–1 disappeared in MOFs 1–3, indicating that all carboxyl groups were deprotonated. Other characteristic absorption peaks were basically consistent with those of the ligands.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD, TGA, and IR Studies

To evaluate the phase purity, PXRD patterns of MOFs 1-3 were recorded. As shown in Figures S25 and S26, the experimental PXRD patterns of polymers 1-3 demonstrate good agreement with the simulated patterns. In addition, the trend of intensity change in the PXRD patterns for 1 and 2 ground for different times indicates that the long-range ordered 3D accumulation structures were gradually destroyed, and peaks marked with asterisks gradually disappear with time (Figure S27). The PRXD of recrystallized sample 3 deposited on a piece of glass verified the process of dissolution and recrystallization in DMF (Figure S26). To examine the thermal stabilities of MOFs 1-3, TGA studies were carried out (Figure S28). The TGA curves of 1 and 2, which resemble each other, show an initial weight loss of 15% (calcd 13.7% for 1; calcd 13.4% for 2) before 165 °C for 1 and 170 °C for 2, corresponding to the weight loss of one free water and one DMF molecule. The rapid weight loss is attributed to decomposition after 300 and 290 °C for 1 and 2, respectively. For 3, there is no obvious weight loss before 250 °C, which suggests that the skeleton is thermally stable, and the weight loss above 270 °C should lead to the collapse of the structure. The IR spectra of all of the organic ligands and the complexes were recorded at indoor temperature (Figure S29). In comparison to carboxylic acid ligands, characteristic peaks of carboxyl groups at 950, 1275, 1690 and 2500-3300 cm-1 disappeared in MOFs 1-3, indicating that all carboxyl groups were deprotonated. Other characteristic absorption peaks were basically consistent with those of the ligands.

elements.content: In summary, a series of new 2D stratified-structure MOFs 1–3 based on the bpb ligand, 5-substituted isophthalic acids, and ZnII were successfully obtained. As the substituents of isophthalic acid change, not only did the structures of the complexes change from a double layer to a single layer but also the regulation of fluorescence emissions was realized. In addition, we studied the acting sites of substituents in the structures using Hirshfeld surface analysis. The double-layer structure of 1 and 2 affords interlayer exciton-related and intralayer excimer-related dual-channel emissions, while 3 with a single-layer structure mainly exhibits intralayer emission. The fluorescent transformation from the emission of interlayer excitons to intralayer excimers can be realized by mechanical grinding and ultrasonication for 1 and 2. In brief, it is an effective strategy to adjust the structure of complexes by using substituent effects to achieve regulation of their properties. In addition, it needs to be especially emphasized that we have proposed a new construction model for exciton materials: i.e., a double-layer MOF.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a series of new 2D stratified-structure MOFs 1-3 based on the bpb ligand, 5-substituted isophthalic acids, and ZnII were successfully obtained. As the substituents of isophthalic acid change, not only did the structures of the complexes change from a double layer to a single layer but also the regulation of fluorescence emissions was realized. In addition, we studied the acting sites of substituents in the structures using Hirshfeld surface analysis. The double-layer structure of 1 and 2 affords interlayer exciton-related and intralayer excimer-related dual-channel emissions, while 3 with a single-layer structure mainly exhibits intralayer emission. The fluorescent transformation from the emission of interlayer excitons to intralayer excimers can be realized by mechanical grinding and ultrasonication for 1 and 2. In brief, it is an effective strategy to adjust the structure of complexes by using substituent effects to achieve regulation of their properties. In addition, it needs to be especially emphasized that we have proposed a new construction model for exciton materials: i.e., a double-layer MOF.

A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (29.7 mg, 0.1 mmol), bpb (6.4 mg, 0.02 mmol), 1,3-H2bdc (3.3 mg, 0.02 mmol), DMF (0.6 mL), and H2O (0.9 mL) was sealed in a 5 mL Teflon-lined reactor and heated at 110 °C for 24 h. When the mixture was cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals of 1 were obtained in 70% yield based on bpb. Anal. Calcd for C29H31N3O7S2Zn: C, 52.53; H, 4.71; N, 6.34. Found: C: 52.81; H: 4.52; N, 6.44.

cln_elements.content: The solid fluorescence of MOFs 1–3 bulk crystals was measured at room temperature (a), showing emission peaks at 536 and 545 nm for 1 and 2 (λex 384 nm) and at 469 nm for 3 (λex 420 nm). Under UV light, the bulk crystal samples of MOFs 1–3 showed different colors of fluorescence: light green for 1, yellow for 2, and light blue for 3 (b). To better study the fluorescence properties of the complexes, the fluorescent emission of all of free ligands was tested at room temperature, as shown in Figure S9. For the bpb ligand, there exist two peaks, at 447 and 535 nm, and for 1,3-H2bdc, H2mip, and H2tbip, the strongest emission peak is at 387, 495, and 320 nm, respectively. Interestingly, the emission peak of the bpb ligand at 535 nm vanished in DMF solution (Figure S9a), which may be due to the loss of ordered intermolecular accumulation.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Photophysical Properties of Bulk Crystals 1-3 

The solid fluorescence of MOFs 1-3 bulk crystals was measured at room temperature (a), showing emission peaks at 536 and 545 nm for 1 and 2 (λex 384 nm) and at 469 nm for 3 (λex 420 nm). Under UV light, the bulk crystal samples of MOFs 1-3 showed different colors of fluorescence: light green for 1, yellow for 2, and light blue for 3 (b). To better study the fluorescence properties of the complexes, the fluorescent emission of all of free ligands was tested at room temperature, as shown in Figure S9. For the bpb ligand, there exist two peaks, at 447 and 535 nm, and for 1,3-H2bdc, H2mip, and H2tbip, the strongest emission peak is at 387, 495, and 320 nm, respectively. Interestingly, the emission peak of the bpb ligand at 535 nm vanished in DMF solution (Figure S9a), which may be due to the loss of ordered intermolecular accumulation.
